title: 110_s1857
content: The "Minority Serving Institutions for Advanced Technology and Education Act" aims to strengthen eligible institutions' capacity in digital and wireless network technologies and enhance the national digital and wireless infrastructure through increased investment in telecommunications and technology infrastructure. Eligible institutions are defined under this Act. The term "eligible institution" in the "Minority Serving Institutions for Advanced Technology and Education Act" refers to historically Black colleges, Hispanic-serving institutions, Tribal Colleges or Universities, Alaska Native-serving institutions, Native Hawaiian-serving institutions, and institutions with a substantial number of minority, low-income students receiving Federal Pell Grants. The term "Secretary" in this Act refers to the Secretary of Education. Minority Serving Institutions for Advanced Technology and Education are addressed in the Act. The Secretary of Education is authorized to award grants to eligible institutions for up to 5 years to carry out specified activities. To receive a grant, an eligible institution must submit an application with a program of activities aligned with the Act's purposes. The Secretary of Education may require additional policies and procedures for grant applications. Regulations will be established for accepting and reviewing applications, with criteria including demonstrated need and diversity among eligible institutions. An eligible institution receiving a grant under this Act must provide non-Federal contributions equal to 25% of the grant amount or $500,000, whichever is less. The matching requirement can be waived for institutions with limited endowments. Grants awarded under this Act must be used for specific purposes outlined in the legislation. An eligible institution receiving a grant under this Act must use the funds for acquiring equipment, providing educational services in STEM fields, offering teacher preparation and professional development, and forming collaborative projects with educational agencies. The curr_chunk focuses on providing education and professional development in technology, science, engineering, and mathematics to eligible institutions through various means such as remote technical support, workshops, and new technologies. It aims to enhance instruction and research in STEM fields using information communications technology. The Act requires eligible institutions to provide data to the Secretary, convene annual meetings for collaboration, and limits grants over $2,500,000. Each eligible institution receiving a grant must submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing the use of the grant. The Secretary will review these reports annually and evaluate the program every two years, describing activities and assessing their impact on students, faculty, and staff. A report to Congress is required within three years. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 3 years of enacting the Act, including recommendations on the need for Federal support for the program. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2008 and the following 5 years is provided under this Act.
